name: 葉采青
objective:
This course aims to help students enhance their comprehension and reading ability of literary works, with the expectation to provide students a better understanding of western literary works as well as to explore students’ interest in literature.
It will be a reading-based course, and in addition to the cultivation of mind, students will be expected to improve vocabulary as well. The instructor intends to center on twelve writers this semester, with the foci on the relationships between the genders in the first eight weeks, and human nature after the midterm exam. Through oral presentations and class discussion, students will have a broader view of how literature is on some level a reflection of “human” life and have the capability to interpret literary works.
schedule:
1.　　Orientation /“Why the Novel Matters,” D.H. Lawrence
2.　　Ernest Hemingway, “Hills Like White Elephants” (1927)
3.　　Kate Chopin, “The Story of an Hour” (1891)
4.　　James Joyce, “Araby” (1914)
5.　　“Araby”/ William Faulkner, “A Rose for Emily” (1930)
6.　　“A Rose for Emily” and critical essays
7.　　Poems
8.　　Review
9.　　Mid-term week
10.　　Anton Chekhov, “The Lady with the Dog” (1899)
11.　　“The Lady with the Dog”
12.　　Sherwood Anderson, “Mother” (1919)
13.　　Flannery O’Connor, “Good Country People” (1955)
14.　　Shirley Jackson, “The Lottery” (1948)
15.　　Franz Kafka, “A Hunger Artist” (1924) 
16.　　“A Hunger Artist”
17.　　Review
18.　　Final week
scorePolicy:
Attendance and participation: 15%
Group presentation: 20%
Midterm exam: 30%
Final exam: 35%
